pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw:
A few `Init` functions accept references to `Manager` classes that are expected to be alive for longer than this class is. These references need to be stored for use by this manager in `RunThreads()`. If the rendering and physics managers are destructed before this class then there could be a crash.

How about changing the references to an `std::weak_ptr`? `sensors::Manager` would lock the weak pointer when updating sensors, then release it. Rendering/physics could be safely destructed without risk of a crash here.
content.html:
A few Init functions accept references to Manager classes that are expected to be alive for longer than this class is. These references need to be stored for use by this manager in RunThreads(). If the rendering and physics managers are destructed before this class then there could be a crash.

How about changing the references to an std::weak_ptr? sensors::Manager would lock the weak pointer when updating sensors, then release it. Rendering/physics could be safely destructed without risk of a crash here.

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw: Weak pointers sound reasonable. The major caveat is the creation of weak pointers, which can only be done from a shared pointer.
content.html: Weak pointers sound reasonable. The major caveat is the creation of weak pointers, which can only be done from a shared pointer.

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw: I think the semantics of a shared pointer are reasonable here. There is one instance of a `rendering::Manager`, it's used in multiple independent places (multiple systems in gazebo), and they all need it to stay alive (to avoid crashing) as long as they're using it.
content.html: I think the semantics of a shared pointer are reasonable here. There is one instance of a rendering::Manager, it's used in multiple independent places (multiple systems in gazebo), and they all need it to stay alive (to avoid crashing) as long as they're using it.

content.raw:
Is this `Enable` method supposed to accept a `SensorId`, or is it meant to enable/disable all sensors?

If it's global, does `Enable(false);` mean `RunThreads()` continues to do work, but no sensor data is produced?

If a sensor is disabled, should `RunOnce(true)` force sensor data generation anyways? Should `RunOnce(false)` make disabled sensors generate data?
content.html:
Is this Enable method supposed to accept a SensorId, or is it meant to enable/disable all sensors?

If it's global, does Enable(false); mean RunThreads() continues to do work, but no sensor data is produced?

If a sensor is disabled, should RunOnce(true) force sensor data generation anyways? Should RunOnce(false) make disabled sensors generate data?

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw:
I recently removed `Camera::ImageDepth` in ign-rendering. In gazebo, we've been mistreating it as number of channels but it's not really what image depth means. For now, you can replace the calculation for `step` with:

~~~
this->dataPtr->camera->ImageWidth() * rendering::PixelUtil::BytesPerPixel(this->dataPtr->camera->ImageFormat())
~~~
content.html:
I recently removed Camera::ImageDepth in ign-rendering. In gazebo, we've been mistreating it as number of channels but it's not really what image depth means. For now, you can replace the calculation for step with:

this->dataPtr->camera->ImageWidth() * rendering::PixelUtil::BytesPerPixel(this->dataPtr->camera->ImageFormat())

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw:
I have linking error when building the example

~~~
[100%] Linking CXX executable save_image
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lignition-math4
~~~

does it need `link_directories`?
content.html:
I have linking error when building the example

[100%] Linking CXX executable save_image
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lignition-math4

does it need link_directories?

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw:
I bet it found ignition-math3 instead. A lot of the ignition libraries currently `find_package(ignition-math3)`, which sets the variable `IGNITION_MATH_FOUND`, which causes `find_package(ignition-math4)` in this package to exit immediately, falsely believing it found version 4. You'll need to build every ignition library that depends on math from source, editing them to depend on 4. 

[This PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/178/make-cmake-variables-use-versioned-project/diff) fixes the issue by making the CMake variables match the project name.
content.html:
I bet it found ignition-math3 instead. A lot of the ignition libraries currently find_package(ignition-math3), which sets the variable IGNITION_MATH_FOUND, which causes find_package(ignition-math4) in this package to exit immediately, falsely believing it found version 4. You'll need to build every ignition library that depends on math from source, editing them to depend on 4.

This PR fixes the issue by making the CMake variables match the project name.

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw:
We might want to make these `REQUIRED`.

Also might want to something like:

```
list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_INCLUDE_DIRS ${IGNITION-MATH_INCLUDE_DIRS})
list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_LIBRARY_DIRS ${IGNITION-MATH_LIBRARY_DIRS})
list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_LIBRARIES ${IGNITION-MATH_LIBRARIES})
```

The above would shorten the `save_image` example CMakeLists.txt to:

```
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.5 FATAL_ERROR)
find_package(ignition-sensors0 REQUIRED)
add_executable(save_image main.cc)
target_include_directories(save_image PUBLIC
  ${IGNITION-SENSORS_INCLUDE_DIRS})
target_link_libraries(save_image PUBLIC
  ${IGNITION-SENSORS_LIBRARIES})
```
content.html:
We might want to make these REQUIRED.

Also might want to something like:

list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_INCLUDE_DIRS ${IGNITION-MATH_INCLUDE_DIRS})
list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_LIBRARY_DIRS ${IGNITION-MATH_LIBRARY_DIRS})
list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_LIBRARIES ${IGNITION-MATH_LIBRARIES})

The above would shorten the save_image example CMakeLists.txt to:

cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.5 FATAL_ERROR)
find_package(ignition-sensors0 REQUIRED)
add_executable(save_image main.cc)
target_include_directories(save_image PUBLIC
  ${IGNITION-SENSORS_INCLUDE_DIRS})
target_link_libraries(save_image PUBLIC
  ${IGNITION-SENSORS_LIBRARIES})

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw:
If I understand correctly,  `find_dependency` wraps `find_package` and passes `REQUIRED` or `QUIET` to match what the user called on `find_package()`. For example if the user does `find_package(ignition-sensors0 REQUIRED)` then this line will call `find_package(ignition-math4 REQUIRED)` too.

I think that shortened example should already work. Instead of appending to variables the libraries use the `target_*()` macros, the `save_image` target links against the `ignition-sensors0` and `ignition-sensors0-camera` targets,  and the project's `*-config.cmake` imports the targets. I put `find_package(ignition-common0)` and `find_package(ignition-rendering0)` in the example because they're used directly in `main.cc` and I want a user to know where they come from.
content.html:
If I understand correctly, find_dependency wraps find_package and passes REQUIRED or QUIET to match what the user called on find_package(). For example if the user does find_package(ignition-sensors0 REQUIRED) then this line will call find_package(ignition-math4 REQUIRED) too.

I think that shortened example should already work. Instead of appending to variables the libraries use the target_*() macros, the save_image target links against the ignition-sensors0 and ignition-sensors0-camera targets, and the project's *-config.cmake imports the targets. I put find_package(ignition-common0) and find_package(ignition-rendering0) in the example because they're used directly in main.cc and I want a user to know where they come from.

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw: This might be wrong, but I think overriding it now allows overriding it in the future without breaking ABI. If it is not overridden, if a user casts to CameraSensor and calls `Init` the compiler would see that CameraSensor does not override the  method and it might de-virtualize the call so it calls `Sensors::Init` directly.
content.html: This might be wrong, but I think overriding it now allows overriding it in the future without breaking ABI. If it is not overridden, if a user casts to CameraSensor and calls Init the compiler would see that CameraSensor does not override the method and it might de-virtualize the call so it calls Sensors::Init directly.

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw:
In this case, you probably want to force a sensor implementation to define the `Init` function. You could make a pure virtual `InitImpl` function in Sensor. Then, `Sensor::Init` would call `DerivedSensor::InitImpl`. 

You could do the same for `Sensor::Load`.
content.html:
In this case, you probably want to force a sensor implementation to define the Init function. You could make a pure virtual InitImpl function in Sensor. Then, Sensor::Init would call DerivedSensor::InitImpl.

You could do the same for Sensor::Load.

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw: Fixed by making `Init()` non-virtual and removing it from `CameraSensor` in 5b441de. Rationale is if a sensor needs to initialize itself it already has `Load()`, so `Init()` is unnecessary.
content.html: Fixed by making Init() non-virtual and removing it from CameraSensor in 5b441de. Rationale is if a sensor needs to initialize itself it already has Load(), so Init() is unnecessary.

content.raw:
I left it out of `src/camera` because its symbols are in the library `ignition-sensors0`. I'm hoping to use the directory structure to communicate that the files in `src/camera` are part of `ignitions-sensors4-camera`. Maybe it would be clearer if this file was moved to `src/camera` and files part of the camera library were one level deeper `src/camera/lib`?

Side note, this file will be replaced by `CameraConfig.cc`.
content.html:
I left it out of src/camera because its symbols are in the library ignition-sensors0. I'm hoping to use the directory structure to communicate that the files in src/camera are part of ignitions-sensors4-camera. Maybe it would be clearer if this file was moved to src/camera and files part of the camera library were one level deeper src/camera/lib?

Side note, this file will be replaced by CameraConfig.cc.
